brief_summary.textblock:
This study aims to investigate the postprandial effects of cocoa supplementation in glucose
      and lipids, and surrogate markers of atherosclerosis in patients with type 2 diabetes. The
      investigators aim to test the hypothesis that cocoa will lower high-fat mixed meal
      breakfast-induced postprandial rise of glucose, lipids and markers of atherosclerosis in
      patients with diabetes. Randomized cross-over controlled trial, in which participants will
      be assigned to the placebo or cocoa group with breakfast meal. Patients with type 2
      diabetes(n=25) will qualify for the study. The participants will be asked to consume 2 cups
      cocoa or placebo beverage on 2 separate postprandial study days. Both groups will receive
      high-fat mixed meal breakfast on each day. Blood draws and blood pressure (including HDI)
      measurements will be conducted at fasting, 30 min, 1,2, 4 & 6 hours postprandial each day
      for 2 days.

clinical_study.brief_title: Cocoa Polyphenols and Postprandial Metabolism in Type 2 Diabetes

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  clinical diagnosis of type 2diabetes

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  on insulin therapy

clinical_study.official_title: Postprandial Effects of Polyphenol-rich Cocoa Beverage on Glucose, Insulin, Lipids, Oxidative Stress and Inflammation in Type 2 Diabetic Patients

primary_outcome.description: Change in blood pressure and vascular function following cocoa and placebo intervention

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Change in glucose levels at fasting, 30min, 1, 2, 4, & 6 hours postprandial following cocoa and placebo intervention

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject), Primary Purpose: Prevention
